div.p: SORITES, in logic, a ſpecies of reaſoning in which a great number of propositions are ſo linked together, that the predicate of the one becomes continually the ſubject of the next following, till at laſt a conclusion is formed by bringing together the ſubject of the firſt propoſition and the predicate oſ the laſt. Such was that merry argument of Themiſtocles, to prove that his little son under ten years old governed the whole world. Thus : My ſon governs his mother ; his mother me; I the Athenians ; the Athenians the Greeks ; Greece commands Europe ; Europe the whole world : therefore my ſon commands the whole world. See Logic, n⁰ 96, 97.
